Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Closed and Open Lateral Internal Sphincterotomy for Chronic Anal Fissure

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with chronic anal fissure, predominantly female (54.9%) and with posterior midline fissures (86.1%).

Intervention.evidence: This study compares the efficacy and safety of closed versus open lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS).

Objective.evidence: This study compares the efficacy and safety of closed versus open lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative healing rate, measured over a follow-up period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation methods varied across studies, with allocation concealment and blinding inconsistently reported.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation methods varied across studies, with allocation concealment and blinding inconsistently reported.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Closed LIS had higher recurrence rates (RR = 1.73, 95% CI 0.86–3.47) and lower incontinence rates (RR = 0.60, 95% CI 0.37–0.96) compared to open LIS.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included postoperative pain and infection, more common in open LIS.
